author: .vshvsh
content: esp. given smart contracts can invalidate signatures

author: djrtwo
content: I'm not sure 0x01 credentials would be given new rights in the future as that might break a security promise of today, but an extended 0x02 following something akin to dankrad's proposal might make sense. That said, arbitrary communication/signal from application layer to the beacon chain has complexity and overhead that needs to be considered

author: jgm
content: I'm not talking about communications from the application layer to the beacon chain, I'm talking about a future beacon chain operation that may be signed with the BLS withdrawal key.  If we can have an assurance that 0x01 credentials can sign any such operations that would pave the way to use 0x01 credentials for future deposits.

author: djrtwo
content: 0x01 can be a smart contract in the application layer so you would have to effectively communicate something across this layer, right?

author: jgm
content: This is more for EOAs than smart contracts.  Basically thinking about using them as a drop-in replacement for BLS keys.

author: lsankar
content: Stated differently, The main use case of 0x00 creds today seems to be as an intermediate state b/w staking and eoa eth1 addresses. So why not just use eoa 0x01 creds in those cases?
